title: Monotributo Tax Regime: Small Business Compliance Gap

formal_rule.text: El Régimen Simplificado para Pequeños Contribuyentes (Monotributo) requiere inscripción obligatoria para actividades económicas con ingresos anuales hasta $9.6 millones, con pagos mensuales fijos que incluyen impuestos nacionales y aportes sociales.
formal_rule.source: Ley 26.565 - Régimen Simplificado para Pequeños Contribuyentes, Artículo 2
formal_rule.sanctions: Multas automáticas por falta de inscripción o pagos atrasados, clausura de actividad, responsabilidad solidaria
formal_rule.scope: Personas físicas y sucesiones indivisas con ingresos anuales hasta $9.6 millones en actividades comerciales, servicios o locaciones

gap_quantification.metric: Percentage of eligible small businesses not registered in Monotributo
gap_quantification.data_source: AFIP - Administración Federal de Ingresos Públicos, Boletín Estadístico Q2 2024

informal_practice.regional_variation: Higher evasion in northern provinces (NOA: 41%, NEA: 38%) vs CABA and GBA (24%), correlating with informality levels

sectoral_variation.description: Higher education levels and formal client expectations drive compliance
Mix of formal stores and informal street vendors
Cash-based transactions, individual clients, low barriers to informality
Complex supply chains, cost competition pressure

primary_causes: Administrative complexity despite 'simplified' regime (12 different categories, quarterly recategorization required)
High effective tax rate for low-income activities (minimum $6,000/month regardless of actual income)
Limited benefits perceived by taxpayers (social security benefits viewed as inadequate)
Weak enforcement capacity (AFIP focuses on larger taxpayers, 1.2% audit probability for Monotributo)
Cultural acceptance of tax evasion in micro-enterprises and self-employment
gap_analysis.enforcement_patterns: Enforcement concentrated on visible commercial establishments; service providers and home-based businesses rarely detected
gap_analysis.temporal_trends: Compliance improved from 58% (2015) to 67% (2024) due to digital payment growth and simplified online procedures
gap_analysis.comparative_context: Better than informal business tax compliance in Brazil (52%) and Mexico (49%), but lower than Chile (78%)

validation.verification_notes: Cross-validated with AFIP registered taxpayers vs INDEC economic survey estimates of eligible businesses

reviewers.name: Dr. Ricardo Fenochietto
reviewers.expertise: Argentine tax policy and small taxpayer regimes

reviewers.name: Dra. Susana Navarrine
reviewers.affiliation: Universidad de Buenos Aires - Derecho Tributario

english_abstract.formal: Argentina's Monotributo simplified tax regime requires mandatory registration for small businesses with annual income up to $9.6 million, featuring fixed monthly payments including national taxes and social contributions.
english_abstract.informal: 33% of eligible small businesses (1.8 million enterprises) remain unregistered, with highest evasion in personal services (47%) and small manufacturing (52%) vs professional services (19%).
english_abstract.gap: Non-compliance driven by administrative complexity despite 'simplified' label, high minimum payments regardless of income, perceived inadequate benefits, weak enforcement (1.2% audit probability), and cultural acceptance of micro-business tax evasion.
